instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Board takes around 88-94 mah, and stays.

No liquid damage signs but it looks like its been ultrasoniced before.

Ive seen boards with no spi rom act sort of this way, so I measured <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. Noticed immediately <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground and 0v, though nothing was getting warm, pch was normal, and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> coming out and to of the pch was present, and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> was present as well.

My question is how should I go about fixing this?  run a wire from <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>? where does <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> come from, to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>?

by the way <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is removed and pin 8 is still shorted on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is removed and pin 8 is still shorted on the board"
Why would you run an wire from <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> to ground?
Eliminate the short first.
Use voltage injection method; start with 1V, no more than 4V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
my fault, by run a wire I mean destroy the pad and then run a wire to pin 8.

injection of 3.3v to that pin skyrockets it to more than 4 amps.

1.0v takes it to over 3 amps. however pch doesnt get hot.

edit: Im struggling to find anything getting hot when injecting voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Set amp limit of the PSU to max; be sure doesn't get into protection mode.

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> rail is extended on the board and may have other points shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
max my psu is taking is 1.38v at 4.5 amps.

I injected it on for a straight minute, 5 times, grabbed all parts, and touched all parts of the board, and not one hot spot.

The things that get hot are my injection probes, thats it.

Could this be a broken trace?. Like a leakage to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Is possible to be short between copper layers.
But you should get a better PSU.
At 2V you may get 8-9A which will heat something for sure.
I recommend many times to get 20A PSU for voltage injection.
Also use ticker cables.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Scratched pin 8 down to just board, then filled with coating, but not over the small hole I made. Pin 8 was fully free, not connected to ground, or anything, then I soldered a wire from pin 5 of <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> to pin 8 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, and yay we now get 3.3v on the spi chip. However still same 94 mah.

Will be uploading voltages shortly

realized pin 7 has a trace connecting to it, and it might have been smarter to just leach off of that but anyway

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: Check now if you have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present on all points of schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
3v3 sus is present everywhere, as well as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>, s3, and <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>. I narrowed it down to <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, pin 13 is 0V, whole circuit looked fishy so I replaced almost all resistors and capacitors, and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>. However still same issue. I noticed pin 13 was 0v but <RESISTOR>R7601</RESISTOR> was 5v. Checked continuity and there is none. Going to run a wire now
this board seems like it was bent or dropped or something before, so many broken traces, most non important tho, these are only two known critical.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: ran wire to pin 13, now <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> gets really hot and shorts to ground. Pin 13 is shorted, as well as 14. I see the line is connected to <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_AGND</SIGNAL>, is this supposed to happen or is <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> just bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: Im going to end this post, as now im noticing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is shorted, pin 1 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is not connected to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, which it should be, its not going to ground either so, too many broken traces, wouldnt sell this to anyone even if fixed, Ive found 10 broken traces already. Thank you 2informaticos for your help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: This board is cracked for sure, very sorry...
